Award.AwardTitle: Structured Retrieval Practice to Enhance Conceptual Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The project supports a series of experimental research studies designed to test improvements in the calibration, reliability, validity, and efficiency of a proto-type tool (Quickscore, a scoring algorithm) that facilitates the examination of structured retrieval practice in learning fundamental concepts in biology. The research systematically examines and tests specific characteristics of structured retrieval practice that have the potential to enhance conceptual learning under different conditions. Building and expanding on previous findings, the project's working hypothesis states that guiding students to practice active reconstruction of their knowledge enhances long-term meaningful learning of complex science materials. While being developed for introductory biology courses, the Structured Retrieval Practice program (software package) is designed to be utilized in all STEM disciplines to enhance learning of fundamental concepts in a discipline. The research contibutes to a growing body of knowledge on the role of retrieval in concept learning. The series of research studies starts under laboratory conditions and concludes with a field-based research study in large introductory courses. An aim of the project is to translate findings from basic researach studies on learning into providing students with a research-based tool that enhances their conceptual learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to develop a computer-based Structured Retrieval Practice program that guides students to practice retrieval while studying and enhances long-term retention of foundational conceptual knowledge. Retrieval practice is an especially effective learning technique, but it remains underused across a broad range of students. Many students struggle to use effective learning strategies when they study on their own, and one approach to addressing this problem is to develop learning technologies that guide students to engage in effective strategies.

In the current work, we developed and enhanced several aspects of our Structured Retrieval Practice program in controlled experiments. We developed new computational methods for automatically scoring students' responses in the computer program. Automated scoring was used to control the sequences of events in the program. We compared our automated scoring methods to students' self-scoring of their answers. One of the key findings was that when students scored their own answers, they tended to be overconfident, awarding full credit for answers that were only partially correct or completely incorrect. We also carried out experiments where we manipulated the types of feedback students received about their responses. Surprisingly, we found that emphasizing and highlighting portions of students' errors did not provide much benefit for student learning, at least within our specific computer program.

Overall, the Structured Retrieval Practice approach was effective for promoting student learning because it leveraged online automated scoring. Having a computer program guide students' study behaviors was effective because it helped ensure that students would practice repeated retrieval, rather than simply retrieving items one time, and because it circumvented the overconfidence that many students experience when they score their own answers.
